title: MAT 106 - Number Systems and Operations - CheckIt Bank

outcomes.title: Proportional Reasoning
outcomes.description: I can solve word problems using proportional reasoning.
outcomes.template:
Solve the word problem below. You must show all work in order to pass. Do not forget to state your final answer, including any appropriate units.

{{problem}}

{{solution}}

F5-E (This explanation skill appears on the back of F5. Passing F5-E is separate from passing F5.)

Explain why proportional reasoning is an appropriate approach to solving the given problem.

Answers will vary.

How do you know that any proportions, diagrams, or equations you used are set up correctly? Explain the process of setting up your solution method as if to a hypothetical student.

Answers will vary.

After you set up your solution method, was there anything tricky or in need of further explanation for a hypothetical student? If so, continue your explanation.

Answers will vary.

data.problem: For every flag of Sylvarant, the ratio of its length to its width must be 35:12. If a Sylvaranti flag is to be produced with a length of 12 ft, what should its width be? Give your final answer as a mixed number, if necessary.
data.solution: If we place the given ratio in a proportion with our known length and unknown width (being careful to attend to matching the order of length and width the numerators and denominators), we get  35/12 = 12/x,  where x is the unknown width. Solving this proportion, we get  x = 4 4/35.

data.problem: Joel and Easton just completed their contract work for the Somy company. Joel worked a total of 42 hours, while Easton worked 82 hours. For their combined work, Somy sent them $4185. If they decide that the fairest way to split the money in a way that reflects the amount of time each of them worked, how much money will each person receive?
data.solution: One way to solve this is by finding the hourly rate for their work. Since they made a total of $4185 over a collective 124 hours of work, we can divide to find that they were making $33.75 per hour. Now, we can multiply this unit rate by each person's hours worked. Doing so shows us that Joel should receive $1417.50, and Easton should receive $2767.50.
